title: Webinar: Energy optioneering: How large companies make energy projects work commercially
lead: This webinar will be brought to you live from 11:00 on December 3rd

title: Up to $40m for improved safety and environmental sustainability in offshore energy
lead: The funding will support research and development related to offshore oil, natural gas, wind and marine hydrokinetic energy production, with a focus on safety, environmental monitoring and operational improvements

title: Offshore wind: Government seeks applications from potential port developers
lead: It has launched a formal competitive process to accelerate the development of large-scale manufacturing portside hubs to create the next-generation of offshore wind turbines

title: New innovation challenge focused on offshore renewable energy launched
lead: Innovators are being sought to identify how marine geospatial data can be used to find suitable sites for offshore wind, tidal and wave energy infrastructure projects

title: IRENA and Ocean Energy Europe team up to accelerate tech commercialisation
lead: They intend to promote the right policy incentives and innovative business models in Europe and globally to help boost ocean energy technologies

title: Solar microgrid ‘to cut Cambodian island’s diesel use by more than 600,000 litres per year’
lead: Total Solar Distributed Generation, in partnership with Canopy Power, is building the infrastructure on the remote island of Koh Rong Sanloem

title: Ørsted fully commissions ‘largest’ Dutch offshore wind farm
lead: The Borssele 1 & 2 offshore wind farm has a total capacity of 752MW, providing enough green electricity to power one million households

title: Northern Powergrid launches fresh call for flexible service providers
lead: The distribution network operator is seeking expressions of interests from generators of electricity, businesses that consume a lot of energy as well as aggregators, among others

title: Plastic waste can cause deformities in marine life
lead: A new study led by scientists from the University of Exeter found sea urchins raised in plastic-contaminated seawater samples suffered from a range of abnormalities, including deformed skeletons and nervous systems

title: Global increases in temperature ‘could be held to 2.1°C by the end of the century’
lead: That’s the suggestion from the Climate Action Tracker group, which previously estimated the planet’s atmosphere could warm by as much as 3°C by 2100
